selected_quotes: Higher pay, lower welfare will leave many low income families worse off #NationalLivingWage htt…
Professor: #NationalLivingWage might not leave you better off
Professor explains why the national living wage might not leave you better off #NationalLiving…
Here's why the national living wage might not leave you better off. Particularly for families.
Professor Donald Hirsh on why the #NationalLivingWage might not leave you better off #NLW

facebook.title: Here's why the national living wage might not leave you better off
facebook.summary:
“Higher pay, lower welfare” – as George Osborne is applying it – is in fact deeply flawed. Low-income families will actually end up worse off, if cuts to welfare continue.

#NationalLivingWage

news.title: Hard Evidence: does income tax and benefits reduce inequality in Britain?
news.summary: The aim of progressive taxation and the welfare state is to redistribute wealth from the richest to the poorest in an effort to erode the worst aspects of poverty and inequality.

news.title: Robin Hood is not Working in the U.K.
news.summary: The aim of progressive taxation and the welfare state is to redistribute wealth from the richest to the poorest in an effort to erode the worst aspects of poverty and inequality.

news.title: Most 'just about managing' families will find life as tough as ever after the Autumn Statement
news.summary: Both the tone and content of Philip Hammond’s first budgetary statement belied the mood music of the past few weeks: that Theresa May’s government will do much more to help “just about managing families” – dubbed the “JAMs”.

news.title: Why we need to take Jeremy Corbyn's earnings cap idea more seriously
news.summary: When Jeremy Corbyn floated the idea of a cap on high earnings in his first big speech of 2017, the Labour Party leader ran into hot water and quickly expanded the idea, mentioning other methods of curbing excessive pay.
